awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Nervous System Adaptations in a Highly Neurotoxic Organism
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Paragraph

Rough-skinned newts (Taricha granulosa) are among the most toxic animals known: some individuals possess enormous quantities of tetrodotoxin (TTX), which prevents brain cells (neurons) from signaling to each other. Scientists know a great deal about how TTX normally blocks neural activity, but not much about how animals that possess TTX are able to resist its effects. The ability of newts to resist TTX is particularly puzzling because several of their genes must be mutated in concert, as a mutation in only one affected gene would leave the newt vulnerable to TTX's affects, and likely dead. Strangely, newts are not simply resistant to TTX's effects, but are actually attracted to the smell of TTX. In the proposed work, the team will use well-established methods to quantify the distribution of TTX inside newts' bodies, identify mutations that are likely involved in TTX resistance, examine the effects of TTX on their neurons, and discover how the neurons involved in smelling are activated by TTX. This basic research will help scientists understand how neurons work at a molecular level, which will increase or understanding of the "nuts and bolts" of healthy brain function, as well as how animals adapt to the presence of toxins. Undergraduate students from under-represented groups, including students from Native American populations in Oregon, will be recruited to participate in summer research programs associated with the work. These experiences will help prepare a diverse population of students for future careers in STEM related fields.

Technical Paragraph

TTX is toxic because it blocks voltage-gated sodium channels (NaVs), essential for the generation and propagation of action potentials. The proposed work will identify where the different forms of NaVs are expressed in neurons and muscles in newts, identify specific mutations in these channels that allow them to resist the toxic effects of TTX, and determine how these structural changes alter neuron function. Using analytical chemistry, histochemistry, and molecular biology, levels of TTX in different tissues as well as the location and structure of the six different NaVs will be examined in both highly toxic and non-toxic newts to quantify levels of TTX resistance and identify mutations that confer resistance. The electrophysiological properties of NaVs in a heterologous expression system and of neurons in the brain of newts will be characterized to determine whether and how TTX resistance alters channel and neuron function. In addition, using a combination of techniques, the adaptations underlying TTX detection in the olfactory epithelium will be identified to understand how this unusual ability evolved. The proposed work will contribute to understanding a physiologically vital class of ion channels, as well as the ways in which evolution at the molecular level shapes nervous system function and animal behavior, thereby deepening our understanding of how neurons function and change over evolutionary time. In addition, the proposed work will immerse undergraduate students in the nature and practice of science, particularly through the involvement of Williamette University students in an REU program at Michigan State University.

por.por_cntn:
Rough-skinned newts (Taricha granulosa) are small salamanders that live along much of the west coast of North America. Many amphibians possess special toxin-storing glands in their skin, and among newts, the toxin is frequently tetrodotoxin (TTX), one of the most lethal neurotoxins known. TTX is the toxin that makes pufferfish sushi exciting to eat, and derives its toxicity from its ability to tightly bind to voltage-gated sodium channels on nerve and muscle cells. TTX blocks the opening in these channels, preventing the flow of sodium and therefore stopping the cells from firing action potentials. Relatively small doses of TTX can lead to respiratory problems and even death, and some individual newts possess enough TTX to kill several adult humans. Our main goal in this project was to understand how newts can possess such a dramatically potent neurotoxin without poisoning themselves, and what kinds of changes might have evolved in newt nervous systems as a consequence.

All vertebrate animals possess several genes that code for voltage-gated sodium channels. Amphibians generally possess six such genes, and we sequenced five of them to look for mutations that might prevent TTX from binding to the channel; the other channel had already been sequenced and characterized by another group. We found that all channels possessed some mutations that were known from other organisms to confer resistance to TTX toxicity, but we also found some new mutations. To examine the effects of uncharacterized mutations we focused on the type of voltage-gated sodium channel that is most widespread in the central nervous system, NaV1.6. We examined the effects of the mutations in NaV1.6 both separately and together and found that the earlier-evolving mutations, which are shared with other salamanders, confer mild resistance to TTX and that the newest mutation confers very high resistance to TTX. Together, the mutations confer resistance to concentrations of TTX that are far higher than would ever be encountered in nature.

As part of our work to understand the relationship between newts and TTX, we discovered that newts do not synthesize TTX themselves, as had been previously thought. Instead, their skin harbors many different kinds of bacteria, and some of these bacteria produce TTX. This result makes sense, as marine animals like pufferfish either get their TTX from bacteria or by eating other organisms that get their TTX from bacteria. This was the first report of TTX-producing bacteria in a freshwater or terrestrial environment, though, and this discovery attracted a lot of attention. We also learned that our newts were infected with Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd), a fungal pathogen that has decimating frog populations worldwide for several decades. Although treatments for Bd in frogs have been widely publicized, treatment protocols for Bd in salamanders had not been described. We collaborated with a campus veterinarian to develop a successful treatment for Bd in newts and other salamanders that we study. We published the first case study of Bd symptoms and treatment in salamanders as well as detailed protocols to allow others to treat this infection in salamanders.

Undergraduate students played key roles in the project, particularly with the bacterial work and with developing and implementing protocols for treating Bd in our salamanders. Several graduate students were also involved, and one earned a PhD for his work on mechanisms of TTX resistance and on the discovery of TTX-producing bacteria in newts. In addition to these research efforts, members of the lab were involved in 'Grandparents University', developing a mini-course on predator-prey interactions for MSU alumni and their grandchildren.
